awd_titl_txt: CAS: Design and Mechanistic Understanding of Selective Electrocatalysts Based on Earth-Abundant Metal Compounds
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award,the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry is supporting Drs. Song Jin and Jordan Schmidt of the University of Wisconsin-Madison to combine theory and experiment to design, develop, and understand new electrochemical methods to generated hydrogen peroxide  (H2O2) from molecular oxygen. Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is an environmentally benign oxidant with many industrial and environmental applications. It is also a recommended disinfectant in general, including for the novel coronavirus responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic. The current commercial production of H2O2 is characterized by significant cost, energy consumption, and safety concerns. To be economically competitive the current process is practiced in a few large, centralized manufacturing plants. In comparison, small scale, decentralized, on-site production of H2O2 directly from oxygen using electricity could be a more effective and sustainable approach. However, electrochemical approaches to H2O2 need to be much more efficient and less costly to be viable. The success of this project can facilitate the efficient decentralized production of H2O2 and have broad technological impacts related to the environment, sustainability, and the healthcare fiels. This project includes a significant educational outreach component and seeks to build a more diverse scientific workforce through inclusive training.


Drs. Song Jin and Jordan Schmidt and their team combine theory and experiment to exploit the unique attributes of unexplored metal compound electrocatalysts to design, develop, and understand new and selective electrocatalysts based on metal chalcogenides for the selective two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (2e ORR) in acidic and neutral solutions. Such selective 2e ORR electrocatalysts can facilitate decentralized electrochemical production of H2O2, an environmentally benign oxidant with diverse applications in industrial, environmental, and healthcare settings. Density functional theory calculations and kinetic models provide detailed insights into activity and selectivity and identify promising candidate structures among transition metal chalcogenides for subsequent synthesis and performance evaluation. Electrochemical and (in situ) spectroscopic studies reveal catalyst activity, selectivity, and potential-dependent reaction intermediates, with computational examination providing mechanistic insights into the catalytic mechanism(s) and further design principles governing catalyst selectivity and stability. Understanding and rationally designing complex metal compound catalysts for enabling various selective electrocatalytic reactions can lead to fundamental and transferrable insights into how complex structural motifs influence catalyst activity and selectivity. The success of this project can also facilitate the efficient decentralized electrochemical production of H2O2 and, as such, has the potential for broad scientific and societal impact.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome Report for CHE-1955074

For August 15, 2020 to July 31, 2023

Project Title: CAS: Design and Mechanistic Understanding of Selective Electrocatalysts Based on Earth-Abundant Metal Compounds
Award Number: 1955074

PIs: Song Jin (e-mail: jin@chem.wisc.edu) and Jordan R. Schmidt (schmidt@chem.wisc.edu)
Institution: University of Wisconsin-Madison
Program Officer: Dr. Kenneth Moloy

      This project seeks to combine theory and experiments to exploit the unique attributes of metal compound electrocatalysts to design, develop, and understand new and selective electrocatalysts based on metal chalcogenides for the selective two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (2e- ORR) in acidic and neutral solutions. Such selective 2e ORR electrocatalysts can facilitate decentralized electrochemical production of H2O2, an environmentally benign oxidant with diverse applications in industrial, environmental, and healthcare settings. The current commercial production of H2O2 is a centralized chemical process with significant cost, energy consumption, and safety concerns. In comparison, decentralized and on-site electrochemical production of H2O2 using electricity (possibly renewably-sourced) to directly reduce oxygen gas could be a more effective and sustainable approach. However, new electrocatalyst materials with high activity, selectivity, and stability need to be developed and carefully evaluated.

      This project has allowed a catalyst materials chemist (Jin) and a computational chemist (Schmidt) to collaborate to go beyond the traditional selective bimetallic catalysts and design and understand novel metal chalcogenide 2e- ORR catalysts for selective electrosynthesis of H2O2. Density functional theory calculations and kinetic models provide detailed insights into activity and selectivity, as well as stability, and identify promising candidate structures among transition metal chalcogenides for subsequent synthesis and performance evaluation. Our integrated computation and experiments have established rational catalyst design rules that successfully led to the discovery of a series of new binary and quaternary earth-abundant metal chalcogenide compounds (as well as a conductive 2D MOF) as selective and robust 2e- ORR catalysts in acidic and neutral solutions. Electrochemical and (in situ) spectroscopic studies revealed catalyst activity, selectivity, stability, and reaction intermediates, with computational examination providing mechanistic insights into the catalytic mechanisms and further design principles governing catalyst selectivity and stability. These systematic studies have led to significant improvements in both H2O2 bulk electrosynthesis performance and catalyst stability. The new and more stable 2e- ORR electrocatalysts in acidic solutions were further exploited for the electro-Fenton process to produce hydroxyl radicals for environmental and electrochemical valorization of biomass-derived feedstock.

Intellectual Merit: In contrast to the more commonly studied catalysts, metal compound catalysts offer many exciting attributes that present unique opportunities for highly selective and efficient electrocatalysis of 2e– ORR, including: presence of several distinct and complex surface binding sites and motifs; dispersed metal sites; and tunability via doping. This collaborative project closely integrated theory and experiments to design, develop, and understand new electrocatalysts based on several classes of metal chalcogenides with different structural motifs that exhibit excellent selectivity for 2e- ORR and good stability for selective 2e- ORR to produce H2O2 in acidic and neutral solutions. This project has yielded new fundamental and transferrable insights into how complex structural motifs influence catalyst activity and selectivity, and the associated design principles for novel selective metal compound electrocatalysts.

 

Broader Impacts: Understanding and rationally designing complex metal compound catalysts for enabling various selective electrocatalytic transformations can lead to fundamental insights and many practical applications. Specifically, selective ORR to H2O2 facilitates the efficient decentralized electrochemical production of H2O2 and has broad technological impacts to environmental, sustainability, and healthcare fields. The facile coupling of the H2O2 electrolysis to the electro-Fenton process to produce the even more potent oxidant of hydroxyl radicals can impact environmental applications and electrochemical valorization of biomass derived molecules. Six graduate students, including an underrepresented student, have been supported or partially supported by this project. So far it has led to six primary publications as well as 3 other publications partially supported by this project. We have developed and run activities on materials and electrochemistry at the Annual Wisconsin Science Festival over the last few years and conducted several demonstrations in local elementary schools (Oregon, WI).


Last Modified: 01/16/2024
Modified by: Song Jin
